title: Lab to determine the launch angle

content.question:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A sphere is launched from below a horizontal surface at an unknown angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal, as shown. It exits the launcher at the surface level. The launcher can be adjusted to give the sphere different launch speeds. Students are to perform an experiment to determine <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown. Assume that the effects of air resistance on the sphere are negligible.

(a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A sphere is launched from below a horizontal surface at an unknown angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal, as shown. It exits the launcher at the surface level. The launcher can be adjusted to give the sphere different launch speeds. Students are to perform an experiment to determine <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown. Assume that the effects of air resistance on the sphere are negligible.

(a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Another group of students perform the same experiment, and they use a sphere with the same diameter as the first group’s but with a larger mass. If the second group follows the same procedure and analysis as described in part (b) through part (d), will the value of the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> obtained with the experiment that uses a heavier sphere be greater than, less than, or equal to the first group’s result from using a sphere that has less mass?

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
